thread.title: DC Download: Startup Connects Vets with Jobs & The SF-DC Tech Divide
thread.title_full: DC Download: Startup Connects Vets with Jobs & The SF-DC Tech Divide

author: Eric Hal Schwartz
title: DC Download: Startup Connects Vets with Jobs & The SF-DC Tech Divide
text:
share Heavy Hitting in DMV Tech 
The Washington Business Journal (WBJ) just revealed its annual “Power 100 of 2015: Heavy Hitters” list, which showcases some of the most influential figures from the DMV area. These names include some of the most powerful executives from massive technology companies, like Lockheed Martin and Capital One Corp. See who’s a “Heavy Hitter.” Full list here. A DC startup finding career mentors for veterans 
Veterans lacking the kind of network that is so often necessary in pursuing a career have a new resource thanks to serial entrepreneurs Leah Wald and Diana Tsai. Find out how Veterati, their new, DC-based startup, connects veterans with mentors able to help guide them to rewarding jobs in our full story here . Baltimore's tech funding future 
TCP Venture Capital has $15 million burning a hole in its pocket to boost Baltimore's tech scene. Partners Christopher College and Stuart Sutley will invest in 10 to 12 new Baltimore-based startups within the next 12 to 18 months. Find out their vision of Baltimore's future in Chris Bing's story here . Is the DC or SF tech scene better 
Just how different is the San Francisco tech scene from the one in DC? Guest writer Alyssa Oursler has seen both up close and shared her take on the good and bad of both coasts. Check out what she's learned and what it means for both cities . Va. fights car hackers 
Virginia hosted a test of new cybersecurity software and hardware intended to protect police vehicles from being hacked last week. It may not have happened yet but it's a threat officials want to cut off ahead of time. Find out how the latest developments in keeping cars safe from hacking in our full coverage of the event here . All the tech news in D.C. you need to know.
